definition:
Let $R$ be a ring with identity. A proper left (right, two-sided) ideal
$\mathfrak{m} \subsetneq R$ is said to be [*maximal*]{} if
$\mathfrak{m}$ is not a proper subset of any other proper left (right,
two-sided) ideal of $R$.

One can prove:

-   A left ideal $\mathfrak{m}$ is maximal if and only if
    $R/\mathfrak{m}$ is a simple left $R$-module.

-   A right ideal $\mathfrak{m}$ is maximal if and only if
    $R/\mathfrak{m}$ is a simple right $R$-module.

-   A two-sided ideal $\mathfrak{m}$ is maximal if and only if
    $R/\mathfrak{m}$ is a simple ring.

All maximal ideals are prime ideals. If $R$ is commutative, an ideal
$\mathfrak{m} \subset R$ is maximal if and only if the quotient ring
$R/\mathfrak{m}$ is a field.
